title: Graphical network model (GNM)
text: Built mrIML architecture (big advantage tidymodels) capability change underlying model easily. going set two models compare: random forest model (RF) logistic regression (LM). mrIML takes advantage multi-core processing, set run 5 cores. steps mrIML (< 2.0.0).
code: future::plan("multisession", workers = 5) model_rf <-rand_forest(   trees = 100,   mode = "classification",   mtry = tune(),   min_n = tune() ) %>%   set_engine("randomForest")  model_lm <- logistic_reg() %>%   set_engine("glm") %>%   set_mode("classification")

title: Graphical network model (GNM)
text: Aside adding JSDM functionality X1 call, also enabled mrIML tune hyperparameters using efficient racing option (see Kuhn (2014)). brief, racing option takes small subsample parameters eliminates combinations improve fit using repeated-measures ANOVA model finetune::tune_race_anova(). Setting racing = FALSE reverts grid search want manually set tuning grid size (.e., using tune::tune_grid()). logistic regression, parameters tune, set racing = FALSE.

title: Graphical network model (GNM)
text: ’s important compare whether advantages using random forest approach. Interpretation easier overall logistic regression gave similar predictive performance.  just look overall AUC values, model performance appears quite similar (0.89 RF 0.78 LM). However, look Matthews correlation coefficient (MCC) taxon LM model, see H.killangoi Plas (Plasmodium), values much lower (overall MCC 0.22 LM basically just guess, compared 0.34 RF). Remember, classes imbalanced, AUC tends inflated measure. provides evidence non-linear relationships can improve predictive performance. Next, ask whether including putative associations taxa improves model performance, whether relationship parasites host relative abundance alone sufficient (.e., assuming independence parasites). can see overall, including associations improves model performance, particularly predicting H.killangoi Microfilaria. Using MCC compare models problematic , association-free model, ’s undefined taxa (NA values arise false negatives low-prevalence taxa). Positive predictive value (PPV) useful case shows without associations, can’t predict occurrence taxa (PPV = 0 ). Including associations increases PPV ~0.2—great, 80% positive predictions taxa false.
code: ModelPerf_rf <- mrIMLperformance(yhats_rf)  ModelPerf_rf[[1]] #across all parasites #> # A tibble: 4 × 8 #>   response     model_name roc_AUC   mcc sensitivity   ppv specificity prevalence #>   <chr>        <chr>        <dbl> <dbl>       <dbl> <dbl>       <dbl>      <dbl> #> 1 Hzosteropis  rand_fore…   0.951 0.714       0.941 0.923       0.758     0.265  #> 2 Hkillangoi   rand_fore…   0.790 0.218       0.918 0.926       0.308     0.116  #> 3 Plas         rand_fore…   0.902 0.438       0.955 0.875       0.4       0.196  #> 4 Microfilaria rand_fore…   0.905 0           1     0.896       0         0.0980 ModelPerf_rf[[2]] #overall #> [1] 0.3426539  ModelPerf_lm <- mrIMLperformance(yhats_lm)  ModelPerf_lm[[1]] #> # A tibble: 4 × 8 #>   response    model_name roc_AUC    mcc sensitivity   ppv specificity prevalence #>   <chr>       <chr>        <dbl>  <dbl>       <dbl> <dbl>       <dbl>      <dbl> #> 1 Hzosteropis logistic_…   0.810 0.335        0.922 0.776      0.346      0.265  #> 2 Hkillangoi  logistic_…   0.657 0.0520       0.975 0.897      0.0526     0.116  #> 3 Plas        logistic_…   0.774 0.119        0.972 0.815      0.0857     0.196  #> 4 Microfilar… logistic_…   0.878 0.362        0.975 0.930      0.294      0.0980 ModelPerf_lm[[2]] #> [1] 0.2169666  plots <- mrPerformancePlot(   ModelPerf1 = ModelPerf_lm,   ModelPerf2 = ModelPerf_rf,   mode = "classification" )  plots[[1]] / plots[[2]] plots[[3]] #> # A tibble: 4 × 6 #>   response  metric_metric_logist…¹ metric_metric_rand_f…² outlier_outlier_logi…³ #>   <chr>                      <dbl>                  <dbl> <lgl>                  #> 1 Hzostero…                 0.335                   0.714 NA                     #> 2 Hkillang…                 0.0520                  0.218 NA                     #> 3 Plas                      0.119                   0.438 NA                     #> 4 Microfil…                 0.362                   0     NA                     #> # ℹ abbreviated names: ¹​metric_metric_logistic_reg, ²​metric_metric_rand_forest, #> #   ³​outlier_outlier_logistic_reg #> # ℹ 2 more variables: outlier_outlier_rand_forest <lgl>, diff_mod1_2 <dbl> yhats_rf_noAssoc <- mrIMLpredicts(   X = X,   Y = Y,   Model = model_rf,   prop = 0.7,   k = 5,   racing = TRUE ) #>   |                                                                              |                                                                      |   0%  |                                                                              |==================                                                    |  25%  |                                                                              |===================================                                   |  50%  |                                                                              |====================================================                  |  75%  |                                                                              |======================================================================| 100%  ModelPerf_rf_noAssoc <- mrIMLperformance(yhats_rf_noAssoc)  ModelPerf_rf_noAssoc[[1]] #> # A tibble: 4 × 8 #>   response     model_name roc_AUC   mcc sensitivity   ppv specificity prevalence #>   <chr>        <chr>        <dbl> <dbl>       <dbl> <dbl>       <dbl>      <dbl> #> 1 Hzosteropis  rand_fore…   0.869 0.544       0.891 0.882       0.647     0.265  #> 2 Hkillangoi   rand_fore…   0.678 0           1     0.948       0         0.116  #> 3 Plas         rand_fore…   0.746 0.475       0.889 0.897       0.593     0.196  #> 4 Microfilaria rand_fore…   0.801 0.459       1     0.947       0.222     0.0980 ModelPerf_rf[[1]] #performance including associations #> # A tibble: 4 × 8 #>   response     model_name roc_AUC   mcc sensitivity   ppv specificity prevalence #>   <chr>        <chr>        <dbl> <dbl>       <dbl> <dbl>       <dbl>      <dbl> #> 1 Hzosteropis  rand_fore…   0.951 0.714       0.941 0.923       0.758     0.265  #> 2 Hkillangoi   rand_fore…   0.790 0.218       0.918 0.926       0.308     0.116  #> 3 Plas         rand_fore…   0.902 0.438       0.955 0.875       0.4       0.196  #> 4 Microfilaria rand_fore…   0.905 0           1     0.896       0         0.0980

title: Graphical network model (GNM)
text: Including associations makes difference, can improve predictions two rarer taxa? Upsampling possible, case, ’ll try downsampling see correcting class imbalance improves model fit. Look PPV values now—much better. false positive rate <6% overall. Now happy performance model, can interrogate .
code: yhats_rf_downSamp <- mrIMLpredicts(   X = X,   Y = Y,   X1 = Y,   Model = model_rf,   balance_data = "down", #down sampling   prop = 0.75,   k = 5,   racing = TRUE ) #>   |                                                                              |                                                                      |   0%  |                                                                              |==================                                                    |  25%  |                                                                              |===================================                                   |  50%  |                                                                              |====================================================                  |  75%  |                                                                              |======================================================================| 100%  ModelPerf_rf_downSamp <- mrIMLperformance(yhats_rf_downSamp) ModelPerf_rf_downSamp[[1]] #> # A tibble: 4 × 8 #>   response     model_name roc_AUC   mcc sensitivity   ppv specificity prevalence #>   <chr>        <chr>        <dbl> <dbl>       <dbl> <dbl>       <dbl>      <dbl> #> 1 Hzosteropis  rand_fore…   0.903 0.600       0.802 0.929       0.844     0.265  #> 2 Hkillangoi   rand_fore…   0.901 0.430       0.740 1           1         0.116  #> 3 Plas         rand_fore…   0.863 0.525       0.739 0.956       0.88      0.196  #> 4 Microfilaria rand_fore…   0.942 0.448       0.760 1           1         0.0980

title: Graphical network model (GNM)
text: many cases, like dataset, community microbiome data tend small size. Applying stochastic machine learning algorithms data can lead challenges. instance, variable importance may vary substantially build multiple models using data algorithm. handle variability better understand prediction uncertainty, mrIML now includes functionality capture uncertainty tuned model using bootstrapping. Additionally, approach helps estimate variables affect response, estimates align traditional linear regression models (see Cook et al., 2021). mrIML makes easy obtain bootstrap estimates variety interpretable machine learning tools uses estimates construct marginalized co-occurrence networks. First, let’s perform bootstrapping calculate variable importance.  can see host abundance important predictor parasite community (followed H.zosteropsis). However, sub-figure right shows substantial variability. example, H.zosteropsis important predictor occurrence Microfilaria, host abundance (shortened “sc..”) less important.

title: Graphical network model (GNM)
text: examine relationship variable community structure, mrIML convenient wrapper plot bootstrapped partial dependencies taxon interest.  plots show presence Microfilaria greatly increases probability observing Plasmodium (~0.47 0.70 holding variables mean value). Note marginal relationships (.e., isolating effect predictor). host abundance high, probability detecting Plasmodium decreases non-linearly (threshold around ~0.5). parasites less effect. explore effect host abundance overall, can use mrCovar() function.  Note isn’t bootstrapped—line represents taxon. second plot shows community-wide average effect taxon-specific effects silhouetted background. third plot shows community-wide average change occurrence probabilities across host abundance. Note occurrence probabilities taxa drop intermediate levels host abundance (0.75–1.25).
code: pds <- mrPdPlotBootstrap(   yhats_rf,   mrBootstrap_obj=bs_malaria,   vi_obj=bs_impVI,   target='Plas',   global_top_var=5 ) pds[[2]] covar <- mrCovar(   yhats_rf,   var = "scale.prop.zos",   sdthresh = 0.01 )  covar[[1]] /   covar[[2]] /   covar[[3]]

title: Graphical network model (GNM)
text: can utilize bootstrapped partial dependence estimates (PDs) construct co-occurrence network. following code converts object igraph object plots . directed network, edges scaled standard deviation marginal change prediction (along PD curves). Red edges positive associations (.e., predicted occurrence increases presence taxon), blue edges negative.
code: assoc_net<- mrCoOccurNet(bs_malaria)  # Based on simulations (not shown here), we use  # the following rule of thumb for associations: # Any association > 0.05 for mean strength is  # included assoc_net_filtered <-  assoc_net %>%    filter(mean_strength > 0.05)  # Convert mrIML to igraph g <- graph_from_data_frame(   assoc_net_filtered,   directed = TRUE,   vertices = names(Y) )  E(g)$Value <- assoc_net_filtered$mean_strength  E(g)$Color <- ifelse(   assoc_net_filtered$direction == "negative",   "blue",   "red" )  # Convert the igraph to a ggplot with NMDS layout gg <- ggnetwork(g)  # Plot the graph gg %>%   ggplot(     aes(       x = x, y = y,       xend = xend, yend = yend     )   ) +   geom_edges(     aes(color = Color, linewidth = Value),      curvature = 0.2,     arrow = arrow(       length = unit(5, "pt"),       type = "closed"     )   ) +    geom_nodes(     color = "gray",      size = degree(g, mode = "out")/2   ) +   scale_color_identity() +   theme_void() +   theme(legend.position = "none")  +   geom_nodelabel_repel(     aes(label = name),     box.padding = unit(0.5, "lines"),     data = gg,     size = 3,     segment.colour = "black",     colour = "white",     fill = "grey36"   ) +   coord_cartesian(xlim = c(-0.2, 1.2), ylim = c(-0.2, 1.2))

title: Graphical network model (GNM)
text: Finally, can quantify overall importance interactions different taxa models, well importance one- two-way interactions specific taxon using bootstrapping approach. quantify interaction importance, use H-statistics hstats package.  first plot shows interactions account average 60% (90% bootstrap uncertainty interval 44–81%) variation predictions H.killangoi, less taxa. second plot shows interactions involving host abundance affect predictions Plasmodium (although H.zosteropis also important , according uncertainty intervals, even important). trend similar community-wide. last plot shows interaction Haemoproteus presence host abundance important two-way interaction Plasmodium, isn’t true community-wide, host abundance H.zosteropis form strongest interaction overall. Taken together, can see interactions taxa mediated host abundance. Finally, can explore specific interactions detail using 2D partial dependence plots implemented flashlight package. , plot two-way interaction host abundance H.zosteropis impacts probability detecting Plasmodium.  , H.zosteropsis present relative abundance Zosterops species low, probability observing Plasmodium high (>0.7).
code: int_ <- mrInteractions(   yhats_rf,   num_bootstrap = 100,   feature = "Plas",   top_int = 10 )  int_[[1]] / # overall plot int_[[2]] / # individual plot for feature int_[[3]]   # two way plot for feature fl <- mrFlashlight(   yhats_rf_downSamp,   response = "single",   index = 4 #index=4 selects Plas )  fl %>%   light_profile2d(     c("scale.prop.zos", "Hzosteropis"),     data   ) %>%   plot() +   theme_bw()

title: Graphical network model (GNM)
text: Cook et al., 2021: https://doi.org/10.18651/RWP2021-12 Kuhn (2014): https://doi.org/10.48550/arXiv.1405.6974 Fountain-Jones et al(2021): https://doi.org/10.1111/1755-0998.13495

title: Microbiome data curation
text: next functions take ASV table data make unique names new column taxa table. Now can start fomatting Y (response data) ready MrIML. includes filtering rare common taxa. Now good go MrIML 2.0 grahical network models can generated!

title: Multi-response (regression)
text: mrIML uses flexible future.apply::future_lapply() set multi-core processing. can greatly speed computationally expensive mrIML functions. example , set cluster using 4 cores. don’t set cluster, default settings used analysis run sequentially.
code: future::plan("multisession", workers = 4)

title: Multi-response (regression)
text: Performing analysis similar classification example. Let’s start constructing linear model data set. set Model 1 linear regression. See https://www.tidymodels.org/find/ regression model options. Note ‘mode’ must ‘regression’ mrIMLpredicts, model set ‘regression’. Model performance can examined way classification example, however reported performance metrics different. Running mrIMLperformance() regression model provides root mean square error (rmse) R². can see overall R² 0.13 substantial variation predictive performance across loci. Let’s compare performance linear model random forest. Random forest computational engine gradient forests. Notice random forests two hyperparameters tune: mtry (number features randomly include split) min_n (minimum number data points node required node split ). syntax tune() acts placeholder tell mrIML tune hyperparameters across grid values (defined mrIMLpredicts tune_grid_size argument). Different algorithms different hyperparameters; see https://www.tidymodels.org/find/parsnip/ parameter details. Note large grid sizes (>10) algorithms lots hyperparameters (extreme gradient boosting) computationally demanding. case choose grid size 5.  can see predictive performance actually slightly less using RF (overall R² = 0.11) loci RF better LM sometimes worse. choose? Generally, simpler better, linear model case, depends important think non-linear responses . future versions mrIML implement ensemble models overcome issue. However, time , ’ll need interrogate model make informed decision.
code: model_lm <- linear_reg() %>%   set_engine("lm") %>%   set_mode("regression")  yhats_lm <- mrIMLpredicts(   X = X,   Y = Y,   Model = model_lm,   prop = 0.7,   tune_grid_size = 10,   k = 10,   racing = FALSE ) ModelPerf_lm <- mrIMLperformance(yhats_lm) ModelPerf_lm$model_performance #> # A tibble: 20 × 4 #>    response           model_name   rmse  rsquared #>    <chr>              <chr>       <dbl>     <dbl> #>  1 CANDIDATE_GI5_108  linear_reg 0.0440  0.290    #>  2 CANDIDATE_GI5_198  linear_reg 0.140   0.392    #>  3 CANDIDATE_GI5_268  linear_reg 0.0847  0.182    #>  4 CANDIDATE_GI5_92   linear_reg 0.0965  0.116    #>  5 CANDIDATE_GI5_1950 linear_reg 0.243   0.000340 #>  6 CANDIDATE_GI5_2382 linear_reg 0.137   0.00896  #>  7 CANDIDATE_GI5_2405 linear_reg 0.145   0.398    #>  8 CANDIDATE_GI5_2612 linear_reg 0.120   0.585    #>  9 CANDIDATE_GI5_2641 linear_reg 0.0669  0.120    #> 10 CANDIDATE_GI5_33   linear_reg 0.167   0.618    #> 11 CANDIDATE_GI5_3966 linear_reg 0.178   0.0244   #> 12 CANDIDATE_GI5_5033 linear_reg 0.0725  0.00277  #> 13 CANDIDATE_GI5_5090 linear_reg 0.136   0.262    #> 14 CANDIDATE_GI5_5119 linear_reg 0.121   0.0118   #> 15 CANDIDATE_GI5_8997 linear_reg 0.194   0.233    #> 16 CANDIDATE_GI5_9287 linear_reg 0.0632  0.0150   #> 17 CANDIDATE_GI5_9447 linear_reg 0.0816 NA        #> 18 CANDIDATE_GI5_9551 linear_reg 0.151   0.192    #> 19 CANDIDATE_GI5_9585 linear_reg 0.177   0.321    #> 20 CANDIDATE_GI5_9659 linear_reg 0.151   0.637 ModelPerf_lm$global_performance_summary #> [1] 0.1284043 model_rf <- rand_forest(   trees = 100,   mode = "regression",   mtry = tune(),   min_n = tune() ) %>%  set_engine("randomForest")  yhats_rf <- mrIMLpredicts(   X = X,   Y = Y,   Model = model_rf,   tune_grid_size = 5 ) #>   |                                                                              |                                                                      |   0%  |                                                                              |====                                                                  |   5%  |                                                                              |=======                                                               |  10%  |                                                                              |==========                                                            |  15%  |                                                                              |==============                                                        |  20%  | |=====================                                                 |  30%  |                                                                              |======================== |======================================                                |  55%  | |============================================================          |  85%  |                                                                              |===============================================================       |  90%  |                                                                              |==================================================================    |  95%  |                                                                              |======================================================================| 100%  ModelPerf_rf <- mrIMLperformance(yhats_rf)  ModelPerf_rf$model_performance #> # A tibble: 20 × 4 #>    response           model_name    rmse rsquared #>    <chr>              <chr>        <dbl>    <dbl> #>  1 CANDIDATE_GI5_108  rand_forest 0.0309  0.0738  #>  2 CANDIDATE_GI5_198  rand_forest 0.0804  0.508   #>  3 CANDIDATE_GI5_268  rand_forest 0.0757  0.658   #>  4 CANDIDATE_GI5_92   rand_forest 0.160   0.352   #>  5 CANDIDATE_GI5_1950 rand_forest 0.141   0.222   #>  6 CANDIDATE_GI5_2382 rand_forest 0.0650  0.0148  #>  7 CANDIDATE_GI5_2405 rand_forest 0.109   0.556   #>  8 CANDIDATE_GI5_2612 rand_forest 0.145   0.0809  #>  9 CANDIDATE_GI5_2641 rand_forest 0.0825  0.00293 #> 10 CANDIDATE_GI5_33   rand_forest 0.154   0.285   #> 11 CANDIDATE_GI5_3966 rand_forest 0.116   0.206   #> 12 CANDIDATE_GI5_5033 rand_forest 0.0438  0.418   #> 13 CANDIDATE_GI5_5090 rand_forest 0.101   0.474   #> 14 CANDIDATE_GI5_5119 rand_forest 0.124   0.0933  #> 15 CANDIDATE_GI5_8997 rand_forest 0.168   0.449   #> 16 CANDIDATE_GI5_9287 rand_forest 0.0528  0.0517  #> 17 CANDIDATE_GI5_9447 rand_forest 0.144 ModelPerf_rf$global_performance_summary #> [1] 0.1086905  #easier to see with plots plots <- mrPerformancePlot(   ModelPerf1 = ModelPerf_lm,   ModelPerf2 = ModelPerf_rf,   mode = "regression" )   plots[[1]] / plots[[2]]

title: Multi-response (regression)
text: first step look variable importance. RF model using mrVip().  figure, top left plot shows ranked important variables across models collectively, subplots top right show important variables top models (number variables models visualize can controlled using global_top_var, local_top_var, threshold arguments mrVip(), see ?mrVip()). bottom plot shows important variables specific response model, defined taxa = "CANDIDATE_GI5_9585". Generally, bio_10 (mean summer temperature), bio_1 (mean annual temperature), bio_18 (summer precipitation) influential predictor variables, however varies quite lot across loci. Summer precipitation important Fitzpatrick et al. otherwise results similar. can also perform PCA variable importance scores different models group loci behave similarly identify outliers.  right plot first two PCs shows candidate 5119, 9287, 5033, 92, 108 shaped similarly features included may, example, products linked selection. left plot shows variability variable importance data captured first three principal components. Note can also supply bootstraps importance scores mrVip(), functionality still development regression models. Next, can explore model plotting relationships SNPs feature set. Let’s choose bio_1 (mean annual temperature) plot individual global (average SNPs) partial dependency (PD) plots.  top plot figure shows partial dependency curves SNPs respond mean annual temperature. mean “respond” prediction surface (line) deviates across Y axis PD plots. measure deviation calculating standard deviation use threshold (sdthresh = 0.01 case, differ data set). middle plot average partial dependency curve SNPs across annual temperature gradient. individual PDs shown grey silhouettes background. similar pattern observed Fitzpatrick et al., except slight decline SNP turnover mean annual temperatures > 0. Combined, can see candidate SNPs driving pattern may warrant interrogation. bottom plot figure shows rate change SNP PD curves. general rise -80 -20. kind plot can help identify general thresholds. Let’s compare PDs accumulated local effect (ALE) plots less sensitive correlations among features (see Molnar 2019). generate ALE plots supplying type = "ale" mrCovar().  effect mean annual temperature SNP turnover distinct global ALE plot. may mean correlations features may important predictions.
code: VI <- mrVip(   yhats_rf,   mrBootstrap_obj = NULL,   threshold = 0.1,   global_top_var = 10,   local_top_var = 5,   taxa = "CANDIDATE_GI5_9585" )   VI[[3]] # PCA VI_PCA <- VI %>%   mrVipPCA()  VI_PCA$eigenvalues #>  [1] 3.35524390 2.35918680 1.80331596 0.97732841 0.71118104 0.64171481 #>  [7] 0.49911497 0.26273404 0.19623715 0.14511906 0.04882385 VI_PCA[[1]] #> Warning: ggrepel: 4 unlabeled data points (too many overlaps). Consider #> increasing max.overlaps PD_bio1 <- mrCovar(   yhats_rf,   var = "bio_1",   sdthresh = 0.01 )  (PD_bio1[[1]] + ylim(0, 0.4)) /   (PD_bio1[[2]] + ylim(0, 0.4)) /   (PD_bio1[[3]] + ylim(0, NA)) #> Scale for y is already present. #> Adding another scale for y, which will replace the existing scale. #> Scale for y is already present. #> Adding another scale for y, which will replace the existing scale. ALE_bio1 <- mrCovar(   yhats_rf,   var = "bio_1",   sdthresh = 0.01,   type = "ale" )  (ALE_bio1[[1]] + ylim(0, 0.4)) /   (ALE_bio1[[2]] + ylim(0, 0.4)) /   (ALE_bio1[[3]] + ylim(0, NA)) #> Scale for y is already present. #> Adding another scale for y, which will replace the existing scale. #> Scale for y is already present. #> Adding another scale for y, which will replace the existing scale.

title: Swine biosecurity
text: synthesized dataset simulate PRRSV infection, biosecurity practices farm demographics swine farms across united states. Please note data included package simulated, reflection real farm, company state.
code: set.seed(130) #set the seed to ensure consistency load("biosecurity_data.RData") data <- biosecurity_vignette_data

title: Swine biosecurity
text: random forest model, used classification example. However models available within MrIML can found .
code: #split predictor variables and outcome Y <- data %>%   select(Class) X <- data %>%   select(-c(1, 44, 45)) model1 <- rand_forest(trees = 1000,               mtry = tune(),               min_n = tune(),               mode = "classification") %>%    set_engine("randomForest")

title: Swine biosecurity
text: MrIML provides uses flexible future apply functionality set multi-core processing. example , set cluster using 4 cores. don’t set cluster, default settings used analysis run sequentially.
code: future::plan("multisession", workers = 2)

title: Swine biosecurity
text: Now can train test model. can assess model performance using number performance metrics including area curve (AUC), sensitivity, specificity Matthews correlation coefficient (MCC).
code: yhats <- mrIMLpredicts(X=X, #features/predictors                         Y=Y, #response data                        Model=model1, #specify your model                        racing=T) #turn off racing autotuning for now #>   |                                                                              |                                                                      |   0%  |                                                                              |======================================================================| 100% ModelPerf <- mrIMLperformance(yhats)  ModelPerf[[1]] #predictive performance for individual responses  #> # A tibble: 1 × 8 #>   response model_name  roc_AUC    mcc sensitivity   ppv specificity prevalence #>   <chr>    <chr>         <dbl>  <dbl>       <dbl> <dbl>       <dbl>      <dbl> #> 1 Class    rand_forest   0.573 0.0292       0.581 0.529       0.448        0.5 ModelPerf[[2]]#overall predictive performance. r2 for regression and MCC for classification #> [1] 0.02916536

title: Swine biosecurity
text: can look variable importance. dependence outcome biosecurity variables. can explore assess partial dependence variable. isolate dependence one variable visualize dependence changes different observed values. ### Benchmarking: predicted risk following function allows visualize compare predicted risk among within groups
code: #calculate variable importance #still got a bug here to do with the PCA impVI <- mrVip(   yhats,   threshold = 0.1,   global_top_var = 10,   local_top_var = 5,   taxa = NULL,   model_perf = ModelPerf )  impVI[[3]] #importance #create a flashlight object fl <- mrFlashlight(yhats,                    response="single",                     index=1)  #plot partial dependence profiles plot(light_profile(fl, v = "Premises_in_3_miles")) +   theme_bw() #apply the trained model to the entire data set to provide risk of predicted outbreak fit_bio <- extract_workflow(yhats$Fits[[1]]$last_mod_fit)  pred_bio <- fit_bio %>%   predict(     new_data = yhats$Fits[[1]]$data,     type = "prob"   )  #... #plot within group comparison of predicted risk mrBenchmark(data = "data1",             Y = "Class",             pred = "Predicted",             group = "Group",             label_by = "ID",             type = "internal")

title: Swine biosecurity
text: investigate interpret contribution variables individual level, must use local explanation method. implement local breakDown explainer. mrLocalExplainer produces aggregated individual results variable contribution. Variables phi > 0 contribute increase predicted PRRSV outbreak risk, variables phi < 0 contribute decrease predicted outbreak risk. Individual plots produced list object LE_indiv_plots. plot corresponds single farm. example positive farm negative farm shown . positive farm can see yards public road garbage collection contributing increased outbreak risk, manure removals repair visits contributing decreased outbreak risk. Likewise, negative farm yards public road downtime required manure removal personnel contributing increased outbreak risk, feed deliveries manure removals contributing decreased outbreak risk. session MrIML funded Critical Agricultural Research Extension 2019-68008-29910 USDA National Institute Food Agriculture.
code: #Use this function to implement the local explainer  data<-data%>%   mutate(Class = revalue(Class,                 c("1" = "Positive", "0" = "Negative")))  data$Class <- relevel(data$Class, "Positive") X1 <- X mrLocalExplainer(X = X1,                  Model = yhats,                  Y = data$Class) LE_indiv_plots[1] LE_indiv_plots[2]

title: mrIML
text: first step mrIML workflow define models like compare. Thanks tidymodels, can define wide range models using unified syntax. demonstrate, going set two models compare: random forest model (RF) logistic regression (lm). models can fit multi-response models using mrIMLpredicts(), work horse mrIML package. mrIMLpredicts() fits supplied tidymodel response variables. X1 argument can used supply response variables like also use predictors; results co-ocurance model (case use response variables). resulting fitted mrIML model list object containing original tidy model, data, fitted response models. remainder functions mrIML package aimed interrogating, explaining, comparing fitted mrIML models.
code: model_rf <- rand_forest(   trees = 100, # 100 trees are set for brevity. Aim to start with 1000.   mode = "classification",   mtry = tune(),   min_n = tune() ) %>%   set_engine("randomForest")  model_lm <- logistic_reg() %>%   set_engine("glm") mrIML_rf <- mrIMLpredicts(   X = X,   Y = Y,   X1 = Y,   Model = model_rf,   prop = 0.7,   k = 5,   racing = TRUE )  mrIML_lm <- mrIMLpredicts(   X = X,   Y = Y,   X1 = Y,   Model = model_lm ,    balance_data = 'no',   prop = 0.6,   k = 5,   racing = FALSE )

title: mrIML
text: mrIMLperformance() another core function mrIML used extract performance metrics fitted response models inside multi-response mrIML model. performance metrics can compared different mrIML model using mrPerformancePlot().
code: perf_rf <- mrIML_rf %>%   mrIMLperformance() perf_rf$model_performance #> # A tibble: 4 × 8 #>   response     model_name roc_AUC   mcc sensitivity   ppv specificity prevalence #>   <chr>        <chr>        <dbl> <dbl>       <dbl> <dbl>       <dbl>      <dbl> #> 1 Hzosteropis  rand_fore…   0.951 0.714       0.941 0.923       0.758     0.265  #> 2 Hkillangoi   rand_fore…   0.790 0.218       0.918 0.926       0.308     0.116  #> 3 Plas         rand_fore…   0.902 0.438       0.955 0.875       0.4       0.196  #> 4 Microfilaria rand_fore…   0.905 0           1     0.896       0         0.0980  perf_lm <- mrIML_lm %>%   mrIMLperformance() perf_rf$model_performance #> # A tibble: 4 × 8 #>   response     model_name roc_AUC   mcc sensitivity   ppv specificity prevalence #>   <chr>        <chr>        <dbl> <dbl>       <dbl> <dbl>       <dbl>      <dbl> #> 1 Hzosteropis  rand_fore…   0.951 0.714       0.941 0.923       0.758     0.265  #> 2 Hkillangoi   rand_fore…   0.790 0.218       0.918 0.926       0.308     0.116  #> 3 Plas         rand_fore…   0.902 0.438       0.955 0.875       0.4       0.196  #> 4 Microfilaria rand_fore…   0.905 0           1     0.896       0         0.0980 perf_comp <- mrPerformancePlot(perf_rf, perf_lm) perf_comp$performance_plot + perf_comp$performance_diff_plot

title: mrIML
text: explore effect predictors different response models, mrIML works closely flashlight package, particularly implementation flashlight::light_profile() generate partial dependency curves (PDs) model agnostic comparisons. mrFlashlight() function can used convert mrIML model flashlight object order apply flashlight functions.  mrCovar() wrapper around mrFlashlight() flashlight::light_profile() quickly compare effect predictive covariate across many response models.  Since PDs model agnostic, can use kind predictive model. example can compare RF model results directly LM bellow. even compare Neural Net enough data fit !  variability response probability across PD curve can used rank variable importance response model. basis, mrVip() compares variable importance across response models inside mrIML model.  many response models /covariates, threshold, global_top_var, local_top_var arguments can used filter variable importance results plotted mrVip. taxa argument can also used plot desired response model may fit filtering criteria. See ?mrVip() specifics arguments.
code: fl_rf <- mrIML_rf %>%   mrFlashlight()  fl_rf$Microfilaria %>%   light_profile(data = data, v = "scale.prop.zos") %>%   plot() +   ggtitle("Effect of scale.prop.zos on Microfilaria") +   theme_bw() PD_scale.prop.zos_rf <- mrIML_rf %>%   mrCovar(var = "scale.prop.zos", sdthresh = 0)  PD_scale.prop.zos_rf[[1]] /   PD_scale.prop.zos_rf[[2]] /   PD_scale.prop.zos_rf[[3]] +   plot_layout(axis = "collect") PD_scale.prop.zos_lm <- mrIML_lm %>%   mrCovar(var = "scale.prop.zos", sdthresh = 0)  PD_scale.prop.zos_lm[[1]] /   PD_scale.prop.zos_lm[[2]] /   PD_scale.prop.zos_lm[[3]] +   plot_layout(axis = "collect") vip_rf <- mrIML_rf %>%   mrVip()  vip_rf[[3]]

title: mrIML
text: quantify uncertainty mrIML model, function mrBootstrap() bootstraps PDs. output can passed mrPdPlotBootstrap() visualize PDs.  bootstrapping PDs, bootstrap information can supplied mrVip() include uncertainty bounds plots.

title: mrIML
text: Another helpful investigative tool mrInteraction(). function quickly identifies response models strong evidence interactions predictors, predictors interactive effects, interactions strongest.
code: interactions_rf <- mrIML_rf %>%   mrInteractions(feature = "Plas", num_bootstrap = 10)  interactions_rf[[1]] /   interactions_rf[[2]] /   interactions_rf[[3]]

title: Authors and Citation
text: Nick Fountain-Jones. Author, maintainer, copyright holder. Ryan Leadbetter. Author. Gustavo Machado. Author. Chris Kozakiewicz. Author. Nick Clark. Author.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Fountain-Jones N, Leadbetter R, Machado G, Kozakiewicz C, Clark N (2025). mrIML: Multi-Response (Multivariate) Interpretable Machine Learning. R package version 2.1.0, https://github.com/nickfountainjones/mrIML.
code: @Manual{,   title = {mrIML: Multi-Response (Multivariate) Interpretable Machine Learning},   author = {Nick Fountain-Jones and Ryan Leadbetter and Gustavo Machado and Chris Kozakiewicz and Nick Clark},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 2.1.0},   url = {https://github.com/nickfountainjones/mrIML}, }

title: Multi-Response (Multivariate) Interpretable Machine Learning
text: package aims enable users build interpret multivariate machine learning models harnessing tidyverse (tidy model syntax particular). package builds ideas Gradient Forests (Ellis et al., 2012), ecological genomic approaches (Fitzpatrick & Keller, 2015), multi-response stacking algorithms (Xing et al., 2020). package can use multi-response machine learning problem, designed handle data common community ecology (site species data) ecological genomics (individual population SNP loci).

title: Multi-Response (Multivariate) Interpretable Machine Learning
text: can install development version mrIML using devtools:
code: install.packages("mrIML")  # Install development version devtools::install_github('nickfountainjones/mrIML')

title: Multi-Response (Multivariate) Interpretable Machine Learning
text: get started, load mrIML tidymodels: Many functions mrIML benefit parallel processing. core function mrIML mrIMLpredicts(), wrapper around tidymodels workflow fits provided model response variable multi-response data set. object mrIML_model can investigated using: mrIMLperformance() get performance metrics response variable, mrvip() get variable importance response variable, mrFlashlight() get partial dependence plots response variable, mrCovar() get covariate importance predictor variable, mrInteractions() get interaction importance predictor variable response models. Two multi-response models can compared using mrPerformance(). Bootstrapping can implemented using mrBootstrap(), can used quantify uncertainty around partial dependence plots, mrPdPlotBootstrap(), variable importance, mrvipBootstrap(), well build co-occurrence networks using mrCoOccurNet().
code: library(mrIML) library(tidymodels) #> ── Attaching packages ────────────────────────────────────── tidymodels 1.3.0 ── #> ✔ broom        1.0.8     ✔ recipes      1.3.0 #> ✔ dials        1.4.0     ✔ rsample      1.3.0 #> ✔ dplyr        1.1.4     ✔ tibble       3.2.1 #> ✔ ggplot2      3.5.2     ✔ tidyr        1.3.1 #> ✔ infer        1.0.8     ✔ tune         1.3.0 #> ✔ modeldata    1.4.0     ✔ workflows    1.2.0 #> ✔ parsnip      1.3.1     ✔ workflowsets 1.1.0 #> ✔ purrr        1.0.4     ✔ yardstick    1.3.2 #> ── Conflicts ───────────────────────────────────────── tidymodels_conflicts() ── #> ✖ purrr::discard() masks scales::discard() #> ✖ dplyr::filter()  masks stats::filter() #> ✖ dplyr::lag()     masks stats::lag() #> ✖ recipes::step()  masks stats::step() future::plan("multisession", workers = 2) # Load example multi-response data data <- MRFcov::Bird.parasites # Split into response and predictor data Y <- data %>%   select(-c("scale.prop.zos")) X <- data %>%   select(scale.prop.zos)  # Define tidymodel model <- rand_forest(   trees = 100,   mode = "classification",   mtry = tune(),   min_n = tune() ) %>%   set_engine("randomForest")  # Fit multi-response model mrIML_model <- mrIMLpredicts(   X = X,   Y = Y,   Model = model,   prop = 0.7,   k = 5 ) #>   |                                                                              |                                                                      |   0%  |                                                                              |==================                                                    |  25%  |                                                                              |===================================                                   |  50%  |                                                                              |====================================================                  |  75%  |                                                                              |======================================================================| 100%

title: Multi-Response (Multivariate) Interpretable Machine Learning
text: Fountain-Jones, N. M., Kozakiewicz, C. P., Forester, B. R., Landguth, E. L., Carver, S., Charleston, M., Gagne, R. B., Greenwell, B., Kraberger, S., Trumbo, D. R., Mayer, M., Clark, N. J., & Machado, G. (2021). MrIML: Multi-response interpretable machine learning model genomic landscapes. Molecular Ecology Resources, 21, 2766–2781. https://doi.org/10.1111/1755-0998.13495 Sykes, . L., Silva, G. S., Holtkamp, D. J., Mauch, B. W., Osemeke, O., Linhares, D. C. L., & Machado, G. (2021). Interpretable machine learning applied -farm biosecurity porcine reproductive respiratory syndrome virus. Transboundary Emerging Diseases, 00, 1–15. https://doi.org/10.1111/tbed.14369 Fountain-Jones, N. M., Appaw, R., Alkhamis, M., Baker, S., Clark, N., Powell-Romero, F., Mayer, M., Machado, G., & Videvall, E. (2024). Advancing ecological community analysis MrIML 2.0: Unravelling taxa associations interpretable machine learning. Authorea [preprint]. https://doi.org/10.22541/au.172676147.77148600/v1

title: Multi-Response (Multivariate) Interpretable Machine Learning
text: Ellis, N., Smith, S. J., & Pitcher, C. R. (2012). Gradient forests: calculating importance gradients physical predictors. Ecology, 93, 156-168. https://doi.org/10.1890/11-0252.1 Fitzpatrick, M. C., & Keller, S. R. (2015). Ecological genomics meets community-level modelling biodiversity: Mapping genomic landscape current future environmental adaptation. Ecology Letters, 18, 1–16. https://doi.org/10.1111/ele.12376 Xing, L., Lesperance, M. L., & Zhang, X. (2020). Simultaneous prediction multiple outcomes using revised stacking algorithms. Bioinformatics, 36, 65-72. https://doi.org/10.1093/bioinformatics/btz531

text: filtered tibble.

title: Bootstrap mrIML model predictions — mrBootstrap
text: function bootstraps model predictions generates variable profiles response variable.

title: Bootstrap mrIML model predictions — mrBootstrap
text: mrIMLobj list object output mrIMLpredicts(). num_bootstrap number bootstrap samples generate (default: 10). downsample Logical. bootstrap samples downsampled? (default: FALSE).

title: Bootstrap mrIML model predictions — mrBootstrap
text: list containing bootstrap samples variable profiles response variable.

code: mrCoOccurNet(mrBootstrap_obj)

text: mrBootstrap_obj list bootstrapped partial dependencies output mrBootstrap().

title: Generate a MrIML co-occurrence network — mrCoOccurNet
text: data frame representing co-occurrence network edge strengths directionality.

title: Generate a MrIML co-occurrence network — mrCoOccurNet

what: Investigate partial dependencies of a covariate for mrIML JSDMs (Joint Species Distribution Models) — mrCovar
title: Investigate partial dependencies of a covariate for mrIML JSDMs (Joint Species Distribution Models) — mrCovar
text: function wrapper around mrFlashlight() plots covariate partial dependencies specified environmental/host variable. also filters taxa based standard deviation thresholds.

title: Investigate partial dependencies of a covariate for mrIML JSDMs (Joint Species Distribution Models) — mrCovar
code: mrCovar(mrIMLobj, var, sdthresh = 0.05, ...)

title: Investigate partial dependencies of a covariate for mrIML JSDMs (Joint Species Distribution Models) — mrCovar
text: mrIMLobj list object output mrIMLpredicts(). var variable interest calculating profile. sdthresh standard deviation threshold filtering taxa (default: 0.05). ... Arguments passed flashlight::light_profile()

title: Investigate partial dependencies of a covariate for mrIML JSDMs (Joint Species Distribution Models) — mrCovar
text: list figures: $partial_dep_curves: covariate partial dependence profiles models meet sdthresh requirement. $partial_dep_avg: average partial dependence profile models. individual model partial dependence profiles silhouetted background. $partial_dep_diff: distribution rates change probability specified variable (derivatives PD curves). Useful identify key threshold values variable.

title: Investigate partial dependencies of a covariate for mrIML JSDMs (Joint Species Distribution Models) — mrCovar
code: mrIML_rf <-  mrIML::mrIML_bird_parasites_RF  covar_results <- mrIML_rf %>%   mrCovar(var = "scale.prop.zos", sdthresh = 0.05)

what: Convert mrIML object into a flashlight object — mrFlashlight
title: Convert mrIML object into a flashlight object — mrFlashlight
text: wrapper function around flashlight::flashlight() run multi-response model-agnostic interpretable machine learning analyses. output can interrogated using core functionality flashlight: see vignette("flashlight", package = "flashlight").

title: Convert mrIML object into a flashlight object — mrFlashlight
code: mrFlashlight(mrIMLobj, response = "multi", index = 1, predict_function = NULL)

title: Convert mrIML object into a flashlight object — mrFlashlight
text: mrIMLobj list object output mrIMLpredicts(). response character string indicating type response: "single" selects one response (indicated index) "multi" selects responses. index numeric value used response "single" select response column data create flashlight object . predict_function function specifying user-defined prediction function (optional).

title: Convert mrIML object into a flashlight object — mrFlashlight
text: flashlight multi-flashlight object.

title: Convert mrIML object into a flashlight object — mrFlashlight
code: library(flashlight) library(ggplot2) data <- MRFcov::Bird.parasites Y <- data %>%   dplyr::select(-scale.prop.zos) %>%   dplyr::select(order(everything())) X <- data %>%   dplyr::select(scale.prop.zos)  mrIML_rf <- mrIML::mrIML_bird_parasites_RF  fl <- mrFlashlight(   mrIML_rf,   response = "multi",   index = 1 )  # Performance comparison fl %>%   light_performance(     metrics = list(`ROC AUC` = MetricsWeighted::AUC)   ) %>%   plot() +   ylim(0, 1)   # Partial dependence curves fl %>%   light_profile(data = cbind(X, Y), "scale.prop.zos") %>%   plot()   # Two-way partial dependence fl %>%   light_profile2d(c("scale.prop.zos", "Plas")) %>%   plot()

what: mrIML: Multi-Response (Multivariate) Interpretable Machine Learning — mrIML-package
title: mrIML: Multi-Response (Multivariate) Interpretable Machine Learning — mrIML-package
text: Builds interprets multi-response machine learning models using 'tidymodels' syntax. Users can supply tidy model, 'mrIML' automates process fitting multiple response models multivariate data applying interpretable machine learning techniques across . details see Fountain-Jones et al. (2021) doi:10.1111/1755-0998.13495  Fountain-Jones et al. (2024) doi:10.22541/au.172676147.77148600/v1 .

title: mrIML: Multi-Response (Multivariate) Interpretable Machine Learning — mrIML-package

title: An example mrIML model fit to MRFcov::Bird.parasites — mrIML_bird_parasites_RF

code: mrIML_bird_parasites_RF

title: An example mrIML model fit to MRFcov::Bird.parasites — mrIML_bird_parasites_RF
text: object class list length 3.

title: An example mrIML model fit to MRFcov::Bird.parasites — mrIML_bird_parasites_RF
text: model_rf <- parsnip::rand_forest( trees = 10, # 10 trees set brevity. Aim start 1000 mode = "classification", mtry = tune::tune(), min_n = tune::tune(), engine = "randomForest" ) mrIML_bird_parasites <- mrIMLpredicts( X = X, Y = Y, X1 = Y, Model = model_rf, prop = 0.7, k = 2, racing = FALSE )

what: Calculate general performance metrics of a mrIML model — mrIMLperformance
title: Calculate general performance metrics of a mrIML model — mrIMLperformance
text: Summarizes performance mrIML object created using mrIMLpredicts() way allows easy comparison different models. regression models, root mean squared error (RMSE) R-squared reported, classification models, area ROC curve (AUC), Matthews correlation coefficient (MCC), positive predictive value (PPV), specificity, sensitivity reported.

title: Calculate general performance metrics of a mrIML model — mrIMLperformance
code: mrIMLperformance(mrIMLobj)

title: Calculate general performance metrics of a mrIML model — mrIMLperformance
text: mrIMLobj list object created mrIMLpredicts() containing multi-response models.

title: Calculate general performance metrics of a mrIML model — mrIMLperformance
text: list two slots: $model_performance: tibble commonly used metrics can used compare model performance classification models. Performance metrics based test data defined mrIMLpredicts(). $global_performance_summary: global performance metric: average performance metric response models. MCC used classification models RMSE regression models.

title: Calculate general performance metrics of a mrIML model — mrIMLperformance
code: mrIML_rf <- mrIML::mrIML_bird_parasites_RF  perf <- mrIMLperformance(mrIML_rf ) perf[[1]] #> # A tibble: 4 × 8 #>   response     model_name roc_AUC   mcc sensitivity   ppv specificity prevalence #>   <chr>        <chr>        <dbl> <dbl>       <dbl> <dbl>       <dbl>      <dbl> #> 1 Hzosteropis  rand_fore…   0.863 0.520       0.913 0.880      0.581      0.265  #> 2 Hkillangoi   rand_fore…   0.763 0.166       0.982 0.855      0.0952     0.116  #> 3 Plas         rand_fore…   0.927 0.640       0.951 0.890      0.636      0.196  #> 4 Microfilaria rand_fore…   0.761 0.376       1     0.917      0.154      0.0980 perf[[2]] #> [1] 0.4253448

what: Generates a multi-response predictive model — mrIMLpredicts
title: Generates a multi-response predictive model — mrIMLpredicts
text: function fits separate classification/regression models, specified tidymodels framework, response variable data set. core function mrIML.

title: Generates a multi-response predictive model — mrIMLpredicts
code: mrIMLpredicts(   X,   X1 = NULL,   Y,   Model,   balance_data = "no",   dummy = FALSE,   prop = 0.7,   tune_grid_size = 10,   k = 10,   racing = TRUE )

title: Generates a multi-response predictive model — mrIMLpredicts
text: Y, X, X1 Data frames containing response, predictor, joint response variables (.e. responses also used predictors fitting GN model) respectively. X1 provided standard multi-response model fit data (e.g. response models independant one another conditional predictors supplied X). See Details section . Model model tidymodels package. See Examples. balance_data character string: "": -samples data equal class sizes. "": -samples data equal class sizes. "": leaves data . "" default value. dummy logical value indicating recipes::step_dummy() included data recipe. prop numeric value 0 1. Defines training-testing data proportion used, defaults prop = 0.7. tune_grid_size numeric value sets grid size hyperparameter tuning. Larger grid sizes increase computational time. Ignored racing = TRUE. k numeric value. Sets number folds cross-validation. 10-fold CV default. racing logical value. TRUE, mrIML performs grid search using finetune::tune_race_anova() method; otherwise, tune::tune_grid() used. racing = TRUE now default method tuning.

title: Generates a multi-response predictive model — mrIMLpredicts
text: list object three slots: $Model: tidymodels object fit. $Data: list raw data. $Fits: list fitted models response variable.

title: Generates a multi-response predictive model — mrIMLpredicts
text: mrIMLpredicts fits supplied tidy model response variable data frame Y. X (data frame predictors) supplied, independent models fit, .e., response variables used predictors. X1 (data frame select response variables) supplied, response variables also used predictors response models. example, supplying X1 means co-occurrence model fit. balance_data = "", themis::step_rose() used upsample dataset; however, generally recommend using balance_data = "" cases.

title: Generates a multi-response predictive model — mrIMLpredicts
code: library(tidymodels)  data <- MRFcov::Bird.parasites  # Define the response variables of interest Y <- data %>%   select(-scale.prop.zos) %>%   select(order(everything()))  # Define the predictors X <- data %>%   select(scale.prop.zos)  # Specify a random forest tidy model model_rf <- rand_forest(   trees = 10, # 50 trees are set for brevity. Aim to start with 1000   mode = "classification",   mtry = tune(),   min_n = tune() ) %>%   set_engine("randomForest")  # Fitting independent multi-response model ----------------------------------- MR_model_rf <- mrIMLpredicts(   X = X,   Y = Y,   Model = model_rf,   prop = 0.7,   k = 2,   racing = FALSE ) #>    |                                                                               |                                                                      |   0%   |                                                                               |==================                                                    |  25%   |                                                                               |===================================                                   |  50%   |                                                                               |====================================================                  |  75%   |                                                                               |======================================================================| 100% #> i Creating pre-processing data to finalize unknown parameter: mtry #> i Creating pre-processing data to finalize unknown parameter: mtry #> i Creating pre-processing data to finalize unknown parameter: mtry #> i Creating pre-processing data to finalize unknown parameter: mtry  # Fitting a graphical network model ----------------------------------------- # Define the dependent response variables (all in this case) # \donttest{ X1 <- Y  GN_model <- mrIMLpredicts(   X = X,   Y = Y,   X1 = X1,   Model = model_rf,   prop = 0.7,   k = 2,   racing = FALSE ) #>    |                                                                               |                                                                      |   0%   |                                                                               |==================                                                    |  25%   |                                                                               |===================================                                   |  50%   |                                                                               |====================================================                  |  75%   |                                                                               |======================================================================| 100% #> i Creating pre-processing data to finalize unknown parameter: mtry #> i Creating pre-processing data to finalize unknown parameter: mtry #> i Creating pre-processing data to finalize unknown parameter: mtry #> i Creating pre-processing data to finalize unknown parameter: mtry # }

what: Calculate and visualize feature interactions — mrInteractions
title: Calculate and visualize feature interactions — mrInteractions
text: wrapper around hstats::hstats(). Calculates visualizes H-statistics interactions model using bootstrapping. See help("hstats") details H-statistics.

title: Calculate and visualize feature interactions — mrInteractions
code: mrInteractions(mrIMLobj, num_bootstrap = 1, feature = NULL, top_int = 10)

title: Calculate and visualize feature interactions — mrInteractions
text: mrIMLobj list object output mrIMLpredicts(). num_bootstrap number bootstrap samples generate (default: 1). feature response model detailed interaction plots generated. top_int number top interactions display (default: 10).

title: Calculate and visualize feature interactions — mrInteractions
text: list containing: $p_h2: ordered bar plot variability response model unexplained main effects. $p_h2_overall: ordered bar plot percentage prediction variability can attributed interactions predictor model specified feature. $p_h2_pairwise: ordered bar plot strength two-way interactions model specified feature. strength interaction taken un-normalized square root H2-pairwise statistic (prediction scale). $h2_df: data frame H2 statistics response model, along bootstraps applicable. $h2_overall_df: data frame H2-overall statistics variable response model, along bootstraps applicable. $h2_pairwise_df: data frame H2-pairwise statistics variable response model, along bootstraps applicable.

title: Calculate and visualize feature interactions — mrInteractions
code: mrIML_rf <- mrIML::mrIML_bird_parasites_RF  mrIML_interactions_rf <- mrInteractions(   mrIML_rf,   num_bootstrap = 50,   feature = "Plas" )  mrIML_interactions_rf[[1]]  mrIML_interactions_rf[[2]]  mrIML_interactions_rf[[3]]

title: Bootstrap Partial Dependence Plots — mrPdPlotBootstrap
text: function extracts plots bootrapped partial dependence functions calculated mrBootstrap() response variable.

title: Bootstrap Partial Dependence Plots — mrPdPlotBootstrap
code: mrPdPlotBootstrap(   mrIML_obj,   mrBootstrap_obj,   vi_obj = NULL,   target,   global_top_var = 2 )

title: Bootstrap Partial Dependence Plots — mrPdPlotBootstrap
text: mrIML_obj list object returned mrIMLpredicts(). mrBootstrap_obj list object returned mrBootstrap(). vi_obj list object returned mrVip(). vi_obj provided, created inside mrPD_bootstrap running mrVip(). target target variable generating plots. global_top_var number top variables consider (default: 2).

title: Bootstrap Partial Dependence Plots — mrPdPlotBootstrap
text: list two elements: [[1]]: data frame partial dependence grid response model, predictor variable, bootstrap. [[2]]: list partial dependence plots predictor variable target response model.

title: Bootstrap Partial Dependence Plots — mrPdPlotBootstrap
Plot Model Performance Comparison — mrPerformancePlot
text: Create visualizations compare performance two models based performance metrics generated mrIMLperformance.

title: Plot Model Performance Comparison — mrPerformancePlot
code: mrPerformancePlot(   ModelPerf1 = NULL,   ModelPerf2 = NULL,   mode = "classification" )

title: Plot Model Performance Comparison — mrPerformancePlot
text: ModelPerf1, ModelPerf2 Two data frames model performance metrics compare. data frames created mrIMLperformance, see Examples. mode character string describing mode models. either "regression" "classification". default "classification".

title: Plot Model Performance Comparison — mrPerformancePlot
text: list containing: $performance_plot: box plot model performance metrics. $performance_diff_plot: bar plot differences performance metrics. $performance_diff_df: data frame wide format containing model performance metrics differences.

title: Plot Model Performance Comparison — mrPerformancePlot
code: MR_perf_rf <-  mrIML::mrIML_bird_parasites_RF %>%   mrIMLperformance() MR_perf_lm <- mrIML::mrIML_bird_parasites_LM%>%   mrIMLperformance()  perf_comp <- mrPerformancePlot(   ModelPerf1 = MR_perf_rf,   ModelPerf2 = MR_perf_lm )

what: Generate SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations) Plots for Multiple Models and Responses — mrShapely
title: Generate SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations) Plots for Multiple Models and Responses — mrShapely
text: function generates SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations) plots multiple models responses.

title: Generate SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations) Plots for Multiple Models and Responses — mrShapely
code: mrShapely(   mrIML_obj,   taxa = NULL,   kind = "beeswarm",   max_display = 15L,   plot_feature_effects = TRUE,   plot_dependencies = TRUE,   plot_2D_dependencies = TRUE )

title: Generate SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations) Plots for Multiple Models and Responses — mrShapely
text: mrIML_obj list object output mrIMLpredicts(). taxa optional character vector specifying responses include. kind character string passed shapviz::sv_importance() specifying type plot parameter (e.g., "beeswarm" feature effect plot, "bar" variable importance plot, ""). max_display integer passed shapviz::sv_importance() specifying maximum number features display. plot_feature_effects logical indicating whether generate feature effect plots (default TRUE). plot_dependencies logical indicating whether generate dependency plots (default TRUE). plot_2D_dependencies logical indicating whether generate interaction plots (default TRUE).

title: Generate SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations) Plots for Multiple Models and Responses — mrShapely
text: list object first element returns SHAP results, following elements contain feature-effect, 1D-dependencies, 2D-dependencies set TRUE input.

title: Generate SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations) Plots for Multiple Models and Responses — mrShapely

what: Calculates and helps interpret variable importance for mrIML models. — mrVip
title: Calculates and helps interpret variable importance for mrIML models. — mrVip
text: Summarizes variable importance mrIML model global (across response models) local (individual response models) level. can done plain mrIML model bootstrap results obtained mrBootstrap().

title: Calculates and helps interpret variable importance for mrIML models. — mrVip
code: mrVip(   mrIMLobj,   mrBootstrap_obj = NULL,   threshold = 0.1,   global_top_var = 10,   local_top_var = 5,   taxa = NULL,   model_perf = NULL )

title: Calculates and helps interpret variable importance for mrIML models. — mrVip
text: mrIMLobj list object output mrIMLpredicts(). mrBootstrap_obj list bootstrap results output mrBootstrap(). threshold performance threshold response models (AUC classification R2 regression). response models meet performance criterion plotted. global_top_var number top global variables display (default: 10). local_top_var number top local variables response display (default: 5). taxa character string identifying response model plotted. model_perf list object containing model performance metrics output mrIMLperformance(). supplied, mrIMLperformance() run inside mrvip() get performance metrics.

title: Calculates and helps interpret variable importance for mrIML models. — mrVip
text: list containing: $vi_data: Variable importance data raw form (including bootstrap samples mrBootstrap_obj supplied). $vi_tbl: Variable importance data point estimates. $vi_plot: grouped plot important variables globally individual response models.

title: Calculates and helps interpret variable importance for mrIML models. — mrVip

what: Principal Component Analysis of mrIML variable importance — mrVipPCA
title: Principal Component Analysis of mrIML variable importance — mrVipPCA
text: Principal Component Analysis mrIML variable importance

title: Principal Component Analysis of mrIML variable importance — mrVipPCA
code: mrVipPCA(mrVip_obj)

title: Principal Component Analysis of mrIML variable importance — mrVipPCA
text: mrVip_obj list returned mrVip().

title: Principal Component Analysis of mrIML variable importance — mrVipPCA
text: list PCA results: $PCA_plot: Side--side plots different response models first two principal components (PCs) Scree plot. $PC_outliers: list models flagged outliers least one PCs. $eigenvalues: eigenvalues associated principal components. $PC_scores: PC scores response model.

title: Principal Component Analysis of mrIML variable importance — mrVipPCA
code: # Without bootstrap mrIML_rf <- mrIML::mrIML_bird_parasites_RF  mrIML_rf_vip <- mrVip(mrIML_rf, taxa = "Plas")  vipPCA_results <- mrIML_rf_vip %>%  mrVipPCA()

title: Conversion to single column per locus from plink file via LEA functionality — readSnpsPed
text: tibble.

title: Conversion to single column per locus from plink file via LEA functionality — readSnpsPed
text: Function import SNP data plink format format suitable MrIML predicts (presence/absence alelle locus). Currently missing data (NAs) either imputes mode leaves . histogram also produced missing data.

title: Conversion to single column per locus from plink file via LEA functionality — readSnpsPed
code: if (FALSE) { snps <- readSnpsPed("FILE_NAME.plink.ped", "FILE_NAME.plink.map.map") X <- filterRareCommon(snps, lower = 0.4, higher = 0.7)  }

what: Calculates resistance components from a list of pairwise resistance surfaces — resist_components
title: Calculates resistance components from a list of pairwise resistance surfaces — resist_components
text: Calculates resistance components list pairwise resistance surfaces

title: Calculates resistance components from a list of pairwise resistance surfaces — resist_components
code: resist_components(foldername = foldername, p_val = p_val, cl = NULL)

title: Calculates resistance components from a list of pairwise resistance surfaces — resist_components
text: foldername character location resistance surfaces stored. p_val numeric sets significance threshold axes explaining variance original resistance matrix based redundancy analysis. effect filters axes explain variance. cl parallel argument passed vegan::capscale() parallel compute wanted.

title: Calculates resistance components from a list of pairwise resistance surfaces — resist_components
text: data frame.

title: Calculates resistance components from a list of pairwise resistance surfaces — resist_components
text: Outputs data frame significant resistance components matrix target folder. data can combined non-pairwise matrix data.

title: Calculates resistance components from a list of pairwise resistance surfaces — resist_components
code: if (FALSE) { Y <- resist_components(filename = 'FILE_PATH', p_val = 0.01) }
